steps.Placing the shelf: Most herbs need a lot of sunlight. Try to place your shelving unit near a window that gets several hours of direct sunlight per day. This will likely be a south- or west-facing window. If your shelving unit has adjustable shelf heights, ensure that as many shelves as possible will receive direct sunlight. Leave enough space between the shelves to avoid squishing the plants
steps.Potting your plants: Once the shelving unit has been placed, you'll need to pot your plants. Make sure the pots you've picked have some kind of drainage, and a saucer or tray beneath them to prevent leakage. Fill the pot about half way with soil. Gently press the soil against the sides of the container, leaving space for the plant to be inserted. Lightly moisten the soil in the pot. Place the plant in the pot and fill in the empty spaces around the sides. Press the soil firmly around the plant and moisten again.
steps.Watering: Your herbs probably require less water than you think. You will need to water them once every 2-3 days. To check whether your plants need water, stick your finger about 2 knuckles into the soil. It should be consistently moist, but not waterlogged. If the soil does not drain properly when you water the herbs, or if the leaves of the herbs begin to wilt and turn yellow, try watering your herbs less frequently. Note that the more sunlight your plants get, the more frequently you should water them
steps.Harvesting: Use a pair of scissors, or pinch gently with your fingers to harvest your herbs. Try to harvest regularly to encourage growth (at least once a week), but avoid removing more than a third of the herbs leaves at a time, as this can kill the plant.
